awd_titl_txt: One-Dimensional Functional Nanocrystals with Non-Precious-Metal Cores and Precious-Metal Shells
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Abstract:
Developing efficient and green energy conversion technologies is of strategic importance for the United States energy and environmental sustainability. Compared with conventional fossil fuel combustion devices, proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) hold great potentials for both transportation and stationary grid applications since they are cleaner, more affordable, and more reliable; they run with renewable hydrogen fuel; and they demonstrate high efficiency with minimized carbon emission. This project aims to develop an emerging class of nanostructured materials with one-dimensional architecture and core/shell structure which can maximize the benefit of PEMFCs. The rational design and precise preparation of such nanomaterials can significantly advance the understanding of both materials design and synthesis for efficient and cost-effective PEMFCs and many other applications, including batteries, electrolyzers, and electrochemical sensors. The outcome of this project can accelerate the large-scale application of PEMFCs, potentially transform the United States energy portfolio, and establish an eco-benign energy society. An education plan is designed to be integrated with research activities to promote teaching, training and learning at several levels, covering K-12, undergraduate and graduate students. Parts of the activities include educational outreach involving underrepresented minorities. The project can attract, build and retain a high-quality next-generation workforce in catalysis, energy technology and other science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) fields.

Technical Abstract:
    Proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs), based on renewable hydrogen sources, play a critical role in establishing a sustainable and clean hydrogen energy economy to reduce our society's dependency on conventional fossil fuels and the related combustion technologies. Advanced PEMFCs suitable for large-scale transportation and stationary grid powers demand a nanostructured material that can be used to accelerate the cathodic oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) with a high activity over a sufficiently long period of time and with minimized platinum group metal usage. The objective of this project is to design and synthesize one-dimensional core-shell nanocrystals with non-precious-metal cores, by precisely controlling their core-shell material compositions and physical parameters (e.g. lengths of one-dimensional nanorods, core-shell interfaces, and shell profiles), to fundamentally understand the correlation of atomic level nanocrystal architecture to the favorable electrocatalytic properties. The Principle Investigator leverages the expertise in nanomaterials synthesis, structural characterization, electrochemistry and theoretical calculation, to primarily focus on four tasks: (1) Rationally designing and synthesizing cobalt phosphide-platinum core-shell nanorods with controlled lengths and shell profiles; (2) Tuning the core-shell interface and structural arrangements; (3) Optimizing the efficiency of nanocrystals by using transition metal doped cobalt phosphide nanorod cores; and (4) Understanding the design rules for optimized ORR conversion through a combination of electrochemical, spectroscopic, and computational approaches. The generated knowledge accelerates the development of new forms of nanomaterials by exploiting the mechanism controls of synthesis at the atomic level and uncovers how to correlate and control their functional activity and structural stability.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RECTOR & VISITORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: This DMR project focuses on the colloidal synthesis of nanomaterials with one-dimensional shape and core/shell structure for the electrolysis. The one-dimensional core/shell structured nanorods with non-precious-metal cores and precious-metal shells are highly promising electrocatalysts for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) in proton exchange membrane fuel cells and other clean energy related catalytic applications (e.g., water electrolyzers, CO2 conversion). At UVA, the research efforts of 5 Ph.D. students and 2 postdocs have been supported by this grant during the past 4 years. This research has resulted in 5 manuscripts including publications in Nat. Catal. (1), J. Am. Chem. Soc. (3), and Nano. Lett. (1) and two others under preparation. The key research products include: [1] A controlled seed-mediated colloidal synthesis was developed to obtain Co2P/Pt core/shell nanorods with well-defined 1 nm of Pt shell and Co2P/Pt core/shell interfaces. The Co2P/Pt nanorods can selectively expose core/shell interfaces that are highly efficient in catalyzing ORR in acid, and therefore exhibit catalytic activity superior to benchmark CoPt alloy and Pt nanoparticle catalyst. [2] A generalized synthesis of Co2P/MPx core/shell and CoMPx solid-solution nanorods were developed, wherein M can be controlled to be Fe, Ni, Mn, Cu, and their binary combinations. The resultant nanorods with uniform one-dimensional (1-D) structure and controllable core/shell structures provides us new opportunities to unambiguously screen the M synergistic effects and core/shell effects in improving the electrocatalytic activity. [3] The developed seed-mediated colloidal synthesis has been expanded to Co2P/Ir, Co2P/Pd, and CoMPx/Pt core/shell nanorods. The Co2P/Ir and Co2P/Pd significantly enhanced Ir and Pd property for electrocatalytic oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) for the water electrolyzers, respectively. In addition, the CoMnPx/Pt is promising to further enhance Co2P/Pt performance for the ORR through Mn incorporation. [4] A new strategy to facilely remove surfactants from colloidally synthesized nanocrystals via a ligand exchange with N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) was developed. This strategy is superior to conventional surfactant removal methods (e.g., calcination, UV ozone cleaning) and applicable to a broad range of precious metal catalysts (including Pt, Pd and Au) for catalyst surface cleaning.

Broader Impacts: Research during the past 4 years of funding has provided training that develops a diverse skill set including expertise in synthesis of nanocrystals, structural characterization of nanocrystals, DFT modeling, and fabrication and testing of electrochemical devices. In the past 4 years, 2 postdocs, 5 graduate students, and 1 undergraduate students at the UVA have participated in research for this project (Note: these postdocs and graduate students were partially supported on this fund). Following research on this project, 3 graduate students are pursuing academia career and working as postdocs after obtaining their PhD (Chang Liu at University of Pennsylvania, Grayson John in the Department of Chemical Engineering at the UVA, and Yulu Zhang at my group). One graduate is continuing his efforts toward his Ph.D. degree. Two postdocs and one graduate student are currently working as senior research scientists in chemical and materials industry (Zhiyong Zhang at Universal Matter Ltd, Meiyang Cui at P&G, and Zhouyang Yin at Seagate Technology). One visiting undergraduate student, Aariella Houston from Bennett College, was involved in the project in the summer of 2019, supported by the NSF funded VA/NC Alliance for Minority Participation Summer Research Program.

A "UVA-Heritage University” pilot program was established by Zhang and colleagues at UVA in 2018 to promote the professional development of students from underrepresented minorities in the physical sciences. Grayson Johnson, a graduate student at the Zhang group visited Heritage University in November 2019 for implementing a hydrogen-energy education module and interacted with over 40 undergraduate students from underrepresented groups.

In the past 4 years, research produced from this project has been broadly disseminated, through 35 seminars and invited talks in professional conferences by the PI and the students. The PI has visited 5 HBCUs and minority institutions, including Hampton University, Norfolk State University, Virginia State University, Clark Atlanta University, and Delaware State University, to disseminate knowledge and establish pipeline to recruit graduate students from underrepresented minority groups.


Last Modified: 01/07/2023
Modified by: Sen Zhang
